FAQ.question: What information does an Encumbrance Certificate show?
FAQ.answer: It shows registered property transactions such as sales, loans, mortgages, leases, release deeds, and cancellations recorded in the SRO.

FAQ.question: Why is Document Type required for an EC search?
FAQ.answer: Document Type helps narrow the search to the correct registered entry when multiple records exist under similar document numbers.

FAQ.question: Does EC show transactions that are still under process?
FAQ.answer: No. Only transactions that have been fully registered and updated in SRO records will appear.

FAQ.question: Can EC track transactions before digital records started?
FAQ.answer: Digital ECs cover online records. Older or manual records may require physical archive requests at the SRO.

FAQ.question: Does EC show legal disputes or court cases?
FAQ.answer: Only if registered as encumbrances. Court cases without registration may not appear and require separate litigation checks.

FAQ.question: Does the EC confirm whether the seller is the real owner?
FAQ.answer: It confirms transaction history, but ownership must be verified through the Sale Deed and supporting documents.

FAQ.question: Is EC mandatory before loan or registration?
FAQ.answer: Yes. Banks and registration authorities typically require EC to verify clear title before approving loans or transfers.

FAQ.question: Does EC include land classification or zoning?
FAQ.answer: No. EC only lists transactions; land classification must be checked through revenue and planning records.

FAQ.question: Can EC show multiple owners or joint ownership?
FAQ.answer: Yes, if the transaction is registered with multiple name entries in the respective deed.

FAQ.question: Is EC from JaaGa authentic?
FAQ.answer: Yes, all EC records are fetched directly from official government registration portals without modification.
